column1: Yangon (Burmese: ရန်ကုန်; pronunciation [jàɰ̃ɡòʊɰ̃ mjo̰]; lit. 'End of Strife')
column2: also known as Rangoon
column3: is the capital of the Yangon Region and the largest city of Myanmar (also known as Burma). Yangon served as the capital of Myanmar until 2006
column4: when the military government relocated the administrative functions to the purpose-built capital city of Naypyidaw [nèpjìdɔ̀] in north central Myanmar. With over 5 million people
column5: Yangon is Myanmar's most populous city and its most important commercial centre.

column1: Yangon boasts the largest number of colonial-era buildings in Southeast Asia
column2: and has a unique colonial-era urban core that is remarkably intact. The colonial-era commercial core is centered around the Sule Pagoda
column3: which is reputed to be over 2
column4: 000 years old. The city is also home to the gilded Shwedagon Pagoda – Myanmar's most sacred Buddhist pagoda.

column1: Yangon was also the burial place where the British sent Bahadur Shah II
column2: the last Mughal emperor
column3: to live in exile after the Indian Rebellion of 1857.

column1: Yangon suffers from deeply inadequate infrastructure
column2: especially compared to other major cities in Southeast Asia. Though many historic residential and commercial buildings have been renovated throughout central Yangon
column3: most satellite towns that ring the city continue to be profoundly impoverished and lack basic infrastructure.

column1: The name Yangon (ရန်ကုန်) is derived from the combination of the Burmese words yan (ရန်) and koun (ကုန်)
column2: which mean 'enemies' and 'run out of'
column3: respectively. This word combination is commonly translated as 'End of Strife'.

column1: Yangon was founded as Dagon in the early 11th century (c. 1028–1043) by the Mon people
column2: who dominated Lower Burma at that time. Dagon became an important pilgrimage pagoda town
column3: starting in the 14th century
column4: during the Hanthawaddy Kingdom. Notable governors of Dagon included Princess Maha Dewi
column5: who ruled the town from 1364 to 1392
column6: and her grandniece
column8: who later became the only female queen regnant in Burmese history. Queen Saw Pu built a palace next to the Shwedagon Pagoda in the town in 1460 and spent her semi-retired life at that palace until her death in 1471.In 1755
column10: the founder of the Konbaung Dynasty captured Dagon
column12: and called the enlarged town "Yangon". In the 1790s
column13: the East India Company opened a factory in Yangon. The estimated population of Yangon in 1823 was about 30
column14: 000. The British captured Yangon during the First Anglo-Burmese War (1824–26)
column15: but returned it to Burmese administration after the war. The city was destroyed by a fire in 1841.

column1: The British seized Yangon and all of Lower Burma in the Second Anglo-Burmese War of 1852
column2: and subsequently transformed Yangon into the commercial and political hub of British Burma. After the war
column3: the British moved the capital of British Burma from Moulmein (present-day Mawlamyine) to Yangon. Based on the design by army engineer Lt. Alexander Fraser
column4: the British constructed a new city on a grid plan on delta land
column5: bounded to the east by the Pazundaung Creek and to the south and west by the Yangon River. Yangon became the capital of all British-ruled Burma after the British had captured Upper Burma in the Third Anglo-Burmese War of 1885. By the 1890s Yangon's increasing population and commerce gave birth to prosperous residential suburbs to the north of Royal Lake (Kandawgyi) and Inya Lake. The British also established hospitals including Rangoon General Hospital and colleges including Rangoon University.

column2: with its spacious parks and lakes and mix of modern buildings and traditional wooden architecture
column3: was known as "the garden city of the East." By the early 20th century
column4: Yangon had public services and infrastructure on par with London.Before World War II
column5: about 55% of Yangon's population of 500
column6: 000 was Indian or South Asian
column7: and only about a third was Bamar (Burman). Karens
column9: the Anglo-Burmese and others made up the rest.

column2: Yangon became the center of the Burmese independence movement
column3: with leftist Rangoon University students leading the way. Three nationwide strikes against the British Empire in 1920
column5: and 1938 all began in Yangon. Yangon was under Japanese occupation (1942–45)
column6: and incurred heavy damage during World War II. The city was retaken by the Allies in May 1945.

column1: Yangon became the capital of the Union of Burma on 4 January 1948 when the country regained independence from the British Empire.

column2: many colonial names of streets and parks were changed to more nationalistic Burmese names. In 1989
column3: the current military junta changed the city's English name to "Yangon"
column4: along with many other changes in English transliteration of Burmese names. (The changes have not been accepted by many Burmese who consider the junta unfit to make such changes
column5: nor by many publications and news bureaus
column6: including
column8: the BBC and foreign nations including the United Kingdom and the United States.)Since independence
column9: Yangon has expanded outwards. Successive governments have built satellite towns such as Thaketa
column10: North Okkalapa and South Okkalapa in the 1950s to Hlaingthaya
column11: Shwepyitha and South Dagon in the 1980s. Today
column12: Greater Yangon encompasses an area covering nearly 600 square kilometres (230 sq mi).During Ne Win's isolationist rule (1962–88)
column13: Yangon's infrastructure deteriorated through poor maintenance and did not keep up with its increasing population. In the 1990s
column14: the current military government's more open market policies attracted domestic and foreign investment
column15: bringing a modicum of modernity to the city's infrastructure. Some inner city residents were forcibly relocated to new satellite towns. Many colonial-period buildings were demolished to make way for high-rise hotels
column18: leading the city government to place about 200 notable colonial-period buildings under the Yangon City Heritage List in 1996. Major building programs have resulted in six new bridges and five new highways linking the city to its industrial back country. Still
column19: much of Yangon remains without basic municipal services such as 24-hour electricity and regular garbage collection.

column1: Yangon has become much more indigenous Burmese in its ethnic make-up since independence. After independence
column2: many South Asians and Anglo-Burmese left. Many more South Asians were forced to leave during the 1960s by Ne Win's xenophobic government. Nevertheless
column3: sizeable South Asian and Chinese communities still exist in Yangon. The Anglo-Burmese have effectively disappeared
column4: having left the country or intermarried with other Burmese groups.

column1: Yangon was the centre of major anti-government protests in 1974
column2: 1988 and 2007. The 8888 Uprising resulted in the deaths of hundreds
column3: if not thousands of Burmese civilians
column4: many in Yangoon where hundreds of thousands of people flooded into the streets of the then capital city. The Saffron Revolution saw mass shootings and the use of crematoria in Yangoon by the Burmese government to erase evidence of their crimes against monks
column5: unarmed protesters
column6: journalists and students.The city's streets saw bloodshed each time as protesters were gunned down by the government.

column2: Cyclone Nargis hit Yangon. While the city had few human casualties
column3: three-quarters of Yangon's industrial infrastructure was destroyed or damaged
column4: with losses estimated at US$800 million.In November 2005
column5: the military government designated Naypyidaw
column6: 320 kilometres (199 mi) north of Yangon
column8: and subsequently moved much of the government to the newly developed city. At any rate
column9: Yangon remains the largest city and the most important commercial center of Myanmar.

column2: a series of coordinated bombings occurred in the city of Yangon
column3: Myanmar. Eleven people were killed in the attack
column4: and one of the 162 people that were injured was a member of the LCMS mission team to Myanmar. This is related to the Lutheran Church in Malaysia.

column1: Yangon is located in Lower Burma (Myanmar) at the convergence of the Yangon and Bago Rivers about 30 km(19 mi) away from the Gulf of Martaban at 16°48' North
column3: 96.15). Its standard time zone is UTC/GMT +6:30 hours.

column1: Yangon has a tropical monsoon climate under the Köppen climate classification system. The city features a lengthy wet season from May through October where a substantial amount of rainfall is received; and a dry season from November through April
column2: where little rainfall is seen. It is primarily due to the heavy rainfall received during the rainy season that Yangon falls under the tropical monsoon climate category. During the course of the year 1961 to 1990s
column3: average temperatures show little variance
column4: with average highs ranging from 29 to 36 °C (84 to 97 °F) and average lows ranging from 18 to 25 °C (64 to 77 °F).

column2: Yangon remained largely constrained to its traditional peninsula setting between the Bago
column3: Yangon and Hlaing Rivers. People moved in
column4: but little of the city moved out. Maps from 1944 show little development north of Inya Lake and areas that are now layered in cement and stacked with houses were then virtual backwaters. Since the late 1980s
column5: however
column6: the city began a rapid spread north to where Yangon International Airport now stands. But the result is a stretching tail on the city
column7: with the downtown area well removed from its geographic centre. The city's area has steadily increased from 72.52 square kilometres (28.00 sq mi) in 1901 to 86.2 square kilometres (33.3 sq mi) in 1940 to 208.51 square kilometres (80.51 sq mi) in 1974
column8: to 346.13 square kilometres (133.64 sq mi) in 1985
column9: and to 598.75 square kilometres (231.18 sq mi) in 2008.

column1: Downtown Yangon is known for its leafy avenues and fin-de-siècle architecture. The former British colonial capital has the highest number of colonial period buildings in south-east Asia. Downtown Yangon is still mainly made up of decaying colonial buildings. The former High Court
column2: the former Secretariat buildings
column3: the former St. Paul's English High School and the Strand Hotel are excellent examples of the bygone era. Most downtown buildings from this era are four-story mix-use (residential and commercial) buildings with 14-foot (4.3 m) ceilings
column4: allowing for the construction of mezzanines. Despite their less-than-perfect conditions
column5: the buildings remain highly sought after and most expensive in the city's property market.In 1996
column6: the Yangon City Development Committee created a Yangon City Heritage List of old buildings and structures in the city that cannot be modified or torn down without approval. In 2012
column7: the city of Yangon imposed a 50-year moratorium on demolition of buildings older than 50 years. The Yangon Heritage Trust
column8: an NGO started by Thant Myint-U
column9: aims to create heritage areas in Downtown
column10: and attract investors to renovate buildings for commercial use.A latter-day hallmark of Yangon is the eight-story apartment building. (In Yangon parlance
column11: a building with no elevators (lifts) is called an apartment building and one with elevators is called a condominium. Condos which have to invest in a local power generator to ensure 24-hour electricity for the elevators are beyond the reach of most Yangonites.) Found throughout the city in various forms
column12: eight-story apartment buildings provide relatively inexpensive housing for many Yangonites. The apartments are usually eight stories high (including the ground floor) mainly because city regulations
column14: required that all buildings higher than 75 feet (23 m) or eight stories to install lifts. The current code calls for elevators in buildings higher than 62 feet (19 m) or six stories
column15: likely ushering in the era of the six-story apartment building. Although most apartment buildings were built only within the last 20 years
column16: they look much older and rundown due to shoddy construction and lack of proper maintenance.

column2: Yangon does not have any skyscrapers. Aside from a few high-rise hotels and office towers
column3: most high-rise buildings (usually 10 stories and up) are "condos" scattered across prosperous neighborhoods north of downtown such as Bahan
column4: Dagon
column5: Kamayut and Mayangon.

column1: Older satellite towns such as Thaketa
column2: North Okkalapa
column3: and South Okkalapa are lined mostly with one to two-story detached houses with access to the city's electricity grid. Newer satellite towns such as North Dagon and South Dagon are in a grid layout. The satellite towns—old or new—receive little or no municipal services.

column1: Downtown Yangon's road layout follows a grid pattern
column2: based on four types of roads:

column1: Broad 49-m wide roads running west to east
Broad 30-m wide roads running south to north
Two narrow 9.1-m wide streets running south to north

Mid-size 15-m wide streets running south to northThe east-west grid of central was laid out by British military engineers Fraser and Montgomerie after the Second Anglo-Burmese War. The city was later developed by the Public Works Department and Bengal Corps of Engineers. The pattern of south to north roads is as follows: one broad 100-foot (30 m) wide broad road
column2: two narrow streets
column3: one mid-size street
column4: two more narrow streets
column5: and then another 100-foot (30 m) wide broad road. This order is repeated from west to east. The narrow streets are numbered; the medium and broad roads are named.

column2: the 100-foot (30 m) Lanmadaw Road is followed by 30-foot (9.1 m)-wide 17th and 18th streets then the medium 50-foot (15 m) Sint-Oh-Dan Road
column3: the 30-foot 19th and 20th streets
column4: followed by another 100-foot (30 m) wide Latha Road
column5: followed again by the two numbered small roads 21st and 22nd streets
column6: and so on.

column1: The roads running parallel west to east were the Strand Road
column2: Merchant Road
column3: Maha Bandula (née Dalhousie) Road
column4: Anawrahta (Fraser) Road
column5: and Bogyoke Aung San (Montgomerie) Road.

column1: The largest and best maintained parks in Yangon are located around Shwedagon Pagoda. To the south-east of the gilded stupa is the most popular recreational area in the city – Kandawgyi Lake. The 150-acre (61-ha) lake is surrounded by the 110-acre (45-ha) Kandawgyi Nature Park
column2: and the 69.25-acre (28-ha) Yangon Zoological Gardens
column3: which consists of a zoo
column4: an aquarium and an amusement park. West of the pagoda towards the former Hluttaw (Parliament) complex is the 130-acre (53-ha) People's Square and Park
column5: (the former parading ground on important national days when Yangon was the capital.) A few miles north of the pagoda lies the 37-acre (15-ha) Inya Lake Park – a favourite hangout place of Yangon University students
column6: and a well-known place of romance in Burmese popular culture.

column1: Hlawga National Park and Allied War Memorial at the outskirts of the city are popular day-trip destinations with the well-to-do and tourists.

Yangon is administered by the Yangon City Development Committee (YCDC). YCDC also coordinates urban planning. The city is made up of 33 townships and is part of Yangon Region. Yangon Region is divided into four districts
column2: which overlap with the city's jurisdiction. The current mayor of Yangon is Maung Maung Soe. Each township is administered by a Township Development Committee
column3: alongside local leaders who make decisions regarding city beautification and infrastructure. Myo-thit (lit. "New Towns"
column4: or satellite towns) are not within such jurisdictions.

Yangon is a member of Asian Network of Major Cities 21.
Yangon is Burma's main domestic and international hub for air
column2: rail
column3: and ground transportation.

column2: located 12 miles (19 km) from the centre
column3: is the country's main gateway for domestic and international air travel. The airport has three terminals
column4: known as T1
column5: T2 and T3 which is also known as Domestic. It has direct flights to major cities in Asia
column6: such as Tokyo
column13: and Dubai. Although domestic airlines offer service to about forty domestic locations

column4: Mandalay

column1: Yangon Circular Railway operates a 45.9-kilometre (28.5 mi) 39-station commuter rail network that connects Yangon's satellite towns. The system is heavily used by the local populace
column2: selling about 150
column3: 000 tickets daily. The popularity of the commuter line has jumped since the government reduced petrol subsidies in August 2007.In 2017 the government of Japan provided more than US$200 million in finance to assist with a range of works including developing and maintaining the Yangon circular railway line
column4: purchasing new carriages and upgrading signalling.

column1: The Yangon Urban Mass Rapid Transit is a proposed rapid transit system
column2: due to begin construction in 2022 and be complete by 2027.
456-kilometre (2
column3: 769 mi) road network of all types (tar
column4: concrete and dirt) in March 2011. Many of the roads are in poor condition and not wide enough to accommodate an increasing number of cars. The vast majority of Yangon residents cannot afford a car and rely on an extensive network of buses to get around. Over 300 public and private bus lines operate about 6
column5: 300 crowded buses around the city
column6: carrying over 4.4 million passengers a day. All buses and 80% of the taxis in Yangon run on compressed natural gas (CNG)
column7: following the 2005 government decree to save money on imported petroleum. Highway buses to other cities depart from Dagon Ayeyar Highway Bus Terminal for Irrawaddy delta region and Aung Mingala Highway Bus Terminal for other parts of the country.Motor transportation in Yangon is highly expensive for most of its citizens. As the government allows only a few thousand cars to be imported each year in a country with over 50 million people
column8: car prices in Yangon (and in Burma) are among the highest in the world. In July 2008
column9: the two most popular cars in Yangon
column10: 1986/87 Nissan Sunny Super Saloon and 1988 Toyota Corolla SE Limited
column11: cost the equivalent of about US$20
column14: imported for the equivalent of around US$50
column17: 000. Illegally imported unregistered cars are cheaper – typically about half the price of registered cars. Nonetheless
column18: car usage in Yangon is on the rise
column19: a sign of rising incomes for some
column20: and already causes much traffic congestion in highway-less Yangon's streets. In 2011
column22: 000 registered motor vehicles in addition to an unknown number of unregistered ones.Since 1970
column23: cars have been driven on the right side of the road in Burma
column24: as part of a military decree. However
column25: as the government has not required left hand drive (LHD) cars to accompany the right side road rules
column26: many cars on the road are still right hand drive (RHD) made for driving on the left side. Japanese used cars
column27: which make up most of the country's imports
column28: still arrive with RHD and are never converted to LHD. As a result
column29: Burmese drivers have to rely on their passengers when passing other cars.

column3: bicycles
column4: and motorcycles. Since February 2010

column6: namely Latha

Ride hailing services operated by private corporations such as Uber and Grab are also available in Yangon today.

column2: all located on or near downtown waterfront
column3: mainly serve local ferries across the river to Dala and Thanlyin
column4: and regional ferries to the Irrawaddy delta. The 22-mile (35 km) Twante Canal was the quickest route from Yangon to the Irrawaddy delta until the 1990s when roads between Yangon and the Irrawaddy Division became usable year-round. While passenger ferries to the delta are still used
column5: those to Upper Burma via the Irrawaddy river are now limited mostly to tourist river cruises. In 2017 October
column6: a New Yangon Water Bus was launched.

column1: Yangon is the most populous city by far in Myanmar. According to the 2014 census
column2: the city had a population of 5.16 million. The city's population grew sharply after 1948 as many people (mainly
column3: the indigenous Burmese) from other parts of the country moved into the newly built satellite towns of North Okkalapa
column4: South Okkalapa
column5: and Thaketa in the 1950s and East Dagon
column6: North Dagon and South Dagon in the 1990s. Immigrants have founded their regional associations (such as Mandalay Association
column8: etc.) in Yangon for networking purposes. The government's decision to move the nation's administrative capital to Naypyidaw has drained an unknown number of civil servants away from Yangon.

column1: Yangon is the most ethnically diverse city in the country. While Indians formed the slight majority prior to World War II
column2: today
column3: the majority of the population is of indigenous Bamar (Burman) descent. Large communities of Indians/South Asian Burmese and the Chinese Burmese exist
column4: especially in the traditional downtown neighborhoods. A large number of Rakhine and Karen also live in the city.

column1: Burmese is the principal language of the city. English is by far the preferred second language of the educated class. In recent years
column2: however
column3: the prospect of overseas job opportunities has enticed some to study other languages: Mandarin Chinese is most popular
column4: followed by Japanese
column5: and French.

column1: The primary religions practised in Yangon are Buddhism
column2: Christianity
column3: Hinduism
column4: and Islam. Shwedagon Pagoda is a famous religious landmark in the city.

column1: Yangon is the country's hub for the movie
column2: music
column3: advertising
column4: newspaper
column5: and book publishing industries. All media is heavily regulated by the military government. Television broadcasting is off-limits to the private sector. All media content must first be approved by the government's media censor board
column6: Press Scrutiny and Registration Division.Most television channels in the country are broadcast from Yangon. TV Myanmar and Myawaddy TV are the two main channels
column7: providing Burmese-language news and entertainment programs. Other special interest channels are MWD-1 and MWD-2
column9: the English-language channel that targets overseas audiences via satellite and via Internet
column10: MRTV-4 and Channel 7 (Yangon) are with a focus on non-formal education programs and movies
column12: a pay-TV channel specializing in broadcasting foreign movies.Yangon has three radio stations. Myanmar Radio National Service is the national radio service and broadcasts mostly in Burmese (and in English during specific times.) Pop culture-oriented Yangon City FM and Mandalay City FM radio stations specialize in Burmese and English pop music
column15: etc. New radio channels such as Shwe FM and Pyinsawaddy FM can also be tuned with the city area.

column1: Nearly all print media and industries are based out of Yangon. All three national newspapers – two Burmese language dailies Myanma Alin (မြန်မာ့အလင်း) and Kyemon (ကြေးမုံ)
column2: and the English language The New Light of Myanmar – are published by the government. Semi-governmental The Myanmar Times weekly
column3: published in Burmese and in English
column4: is mainly geared for Yangon's expatriate community. Over twenty special interest journals and magazines covering sports
column5: fashion
column6: finance
column8: literature (but never politics) vie for the readership of the general populace.

column1: Access to foreign media is extremely difficult. Satellite television in Yangon
column2: and in Burma
column3: is very expensive as the government imposes an annual registration fee of one million kyats. Certain foreign newspapers and periodicals such as the Straits Times can be found only in a few (mostly downtown) bookstores. Internet access in Yangon
column4: which has the best telecommunication infrastructure in the country
column5: is slow and erratic at best
column6: and the Burmese government implements one of the world's most restrictive regimes of Internet control. International text messaging and voice messaging was permitted only in August 2008.

column1: Common facilities taken for granted elsewhere are luxury prized items in Yangon and Burma. The price of a GSM mobile phone was about K1.1 million in August 2008. In 2007
column2: the country of 55 million had only 775
column3: 000 phone lines (including 275
column4: 000 mobile phones)
column5: and 400
column6: 000 computers. Even in Yangon
column8: the estimated telephone penetration rate was only 6% at the end of 2004
column9: and the official waiting time for a telephone line was 3.6 years. Most people cannot afford a computer and have to use the city's numerous Internet cafes to access a heavily restricted Internet
column10: and a heavily censored local intranet. According to official statistics
column14: with the vast majority hailing from just two cities

column1: Yangon's property market is the most expensive in the country and beyond the reach of most Yangonites. Most rent outside the centre and few can afford to rent such apartments. (In 2008
column2: rents for a typical 650-to-750-square-foot (60 to 70 m2) apartments in the centre and vicinity range between K70
column3: 000 and K150
column4: 000 and those for high end condos between K200
column5: 000 and K500

column1: Most men of all ages (and some women) spend their time at ubiquitous tea-shops
column2: found in any corner or street of the city. Watching European football (mostly English Premier League with occasional La Liga
column3: Serie A
column4: Bundesliga) matches while sipping tea is a popular pastime among many Yangonites. The average person stays close to his or her residential neighborhood. The well-to-do tend to visit shopping malls and parks on weekends. Some leave the city on weekends for Chaungtha and Ngwesaung beach resorts in Ayeyarwady Division.

column1: Yangon is also home to many pagoda festivals (paya pwe)
column2: held during dry-season months (November – March). The most famous of all
column3: the Shwedagon Pagoda Festival in March
column4: attracts thousands of pilgrims from around the country.

column1: Yangon's museums are the domain of tourists and rarely visited by the locals.
Most of Yangon's larger hotels offer some kind of nightlife entertainment
column2: geared towards tourists and the well-to-do Burmese. Some hotels offer traditional Burmese performing arts shows complete with a traditional Burmese orchestra. The pub scene in larger hotels is more or less the same as elsewhere in Asia. Other options include karaoke bars and pub restaurants in Yangon Chinatown.

column1: Due to the problems of high inflation
column2: the lack of high denomination notes
column3: and the fact that many of the population do not have access to checks
column4: or credit or debit cards
column5: it is common to see citizens carrying a considerable amount of cash. (The highest denomination of Burmese currency kyat is 10 000 (~US$10.)) Credit cards are only rarely used in the city
column6: chiefly in the more lavish hotels. Credit cards are also accepted in the major supermarket and convenience store chains.

column1: As the city has the best sporting facilities in the country
column2: most national-level annual sporting tournaments such as track and field
column3: football
column4: volleyball
column5: tennis and swimming are held in Yangon. The 40
column6: 000-seat Aung San Stadium and the 32
column7: 000-seat Thuwunna Stadium are the main venues for the highly popular annual State and Division football tournament. Until April 2009
column10: played all its matches in Yangon stadiums
column11: and attracted little interest from the general public or commercial success despite the enormous popularity of football in Burma. Most Yangonites prefer watching European football on satellite TV. Teams such as Manchester United
column17: and Manchester City are among the favorite European teams among the Yangonites. It remains to be seen whether the Myanmar National League
column18: the country's first professional football league
column19: and its Yangon-based club Yangon United FC will attract a sufficient following in the country's most important media market.

column1: Yangon is also home to annual the Myanmar Open golf tournament
column2: and the Myanmar Open tennis tournament. The city hosted the 1961 and 1969 South East Asian Games. During colonial times
column3: cricket was played mostly by British officials in the city. First-class cricket was played in the city in January 1927 when the touring Marylebone Cricket Club played Burma and the Rangoon Gymkhana. Two grounds were used to host these matches
column4: the BAA Ground and the Gymkhana Ground. These matches mark the only time Burma and Rangoon Gymkhana have appeared in first-class cricket
column5: and the only time first-class cricket has been played in Burma. After independence cricket all but died out in the country.

column1: Yangon has a growing population of skateboarders
column2: as documented in the films Altered Focus: Burma and Youth of Yangon. German non-profit organization Make Life Skate Life has received permission from the Yangon City Development Committee to construct a concrete skatepark at Thakin Mya park in downtown
column3: and plans to complete the park in November 2015.

column1: Yangon is the country's main centre for trade
column2: industry
column3: real estate
column4: media
column5: entertainment and tourism. The city represents about one fifth of the national economy. According to official statistics for FY 2010–2011
column6: the size of the economy of Yangon Region was 8.93 trillion kyats

column1: The city is Lower Burma's main trading hub for all kinds of merchandise – from basic foodstuffs to used cars although commerce continues to be hampered by the city's severely underdeveloped banking industry and communication infrastructure. Bayinnaung Market is the largest wholesale center in the country for rice
column2: beans and pulses
column3: and other agricultural commodities. Much of the country's legal imports and exports go through Thilawa Port
column4: the largest and busiest port in Burma. There is also a great deal of informal trade
column5: especially in street markets that exist alongside street platforms of Downtown Yangon's townships. However
column6: on 17 June 2011
column7: the YCDC announced that street vendors
column8: who had previously been allowed to legally open shop at 3  pm
column9: would be prohibited from selling on the streets
column10: and permitted to sell only in their townships of residence
column11: presumably to clean up the city's image. Since 1 December 2009
column12: high-density polyethylene plastic bags have been banned by city authorities.Manufacturing accounts for a sizeable share of employment. At least 14 light industrial zones ring Yangon
column15: 300 factories in early 2010. The city is the centre of country's garment industry which exported US$292 million in 2008/9 fiscal year. More than 80 percent of factory workers in Yangon work on a day-to-day basis. Most are young women between 15 and 27 years of age who come from the countryside in search of a better life. The manufacturing sector suffers from both structural problems (e.g. chronic power shortages) and political problems (e.g. economic sanctions). In 2008
column16: Yangon's 2500 factories alone needed about 120 MW of power; yet
column17: the entire city received only about 250 MW of the 530 MW needed. Chronic power shortages limit the factories' operating hours between 8 am and 6 pm.Construction is a major source of employment. The construction industry has been negatively affected by the move of state apparatus and civil servants to Naypyidaw
column18: new regulations introduced in August 2009 requiring builders to provide at least 12 parking spaces in every new high-rise building
column19: and the general poor business climate. As of January 2010
column20: the number of new high-rise building starts approved in 2009–2010 was only 334
column21: compared to 582 in 2008–2009.Tourism represents a major source of foreign currency for the city although by south-east Asian standards the number of foreign visitors to Yangon has always been quite low—about 250
column22: 000 before the Saffron Revolution in September 2007. The number of visitors dipped even further following the Saffron Revolution and Cyclone Nargis. The recent improvement in the country's political climate has attracted an increasing number of businessmen and tourists. Between 300
column24: 000 visitors that went through Yangon International in 2011. However
column26: Yangon's modest hotel infrastructure—only 3000 of the total 8000 hotel rooms in Yangon are "suitable for tourists"—is already bursting at seams
column27: and will need to be expanded to handle additional visitors. As part of an urban development strategy
column28: a hotel zone has been planned in Yangon's outskirts
column29: encompassing government- and military-owned land in Mingaladon

column1: Yangon educational facilities has a very high number of qualified teachers but the state spending on education is among the lowest of the world. Around 2007 estimate by the London-based International Institute for Strategic Studies puts the spending for education at 0.5% of the national budget. The disparity in educational opportunities and achievement between rich and poor schools is quite stark even within the city. With little or no state support forthcoming
column2: schools have to rely on forced "donations" and various fees from parents for nearly everything – school maintenance to teachers' salaries
column3: forcing many poor students to drop out.

column16: the nation's oldest university is now mostly a graduate school
column17: deprived of undergraduate studies. Following the 1988 nationwide uprising
column18: the military government has repeatedly closed universities
column19: and has dispersed most of the undergraduate student population to new universities in the suburbs such as Dagon University
column20: the University of East Yangon and the University of West Yangon. Nonetheless
column21: many of the country's most selective universities are still in Yangon. Students from around the country still have to come to study in Yangon as some subjects are offered only at its universities. The University of Medicine 1
column24: University of Computer Studies and Myanmar Maritime University are the most selective in the country.

column1: The general state of health care in Yangon is poor. According to a 2007 estimate
column2: the military government spends 0.4% of the national budget on health care
column3: and 40% to 60% on defence. By the government's own figures
column4: it spends 849 kyats (US$0.85) per person. Although health care is nominally free
column5: in reality
column6: patients have to pay for medicine and treatment
column7: even in public clinics and hospitals. Public hospitals including the flagship Yangon General Hospital lack many of the basic facilities and equipment.

column1: Wealthier Yangonites still have access to country's best medical facilities and internationally qualified doctors. Only Yangon and Mandalay have any sizeable number of doctors left as many Burmese doctors have emigrated. The well-to-do go to private clinics or hospitals like Pun Hlaing International Hospital and Bahosi Medical Clinic. Medical malpractice is widespread
column2: even in private clinics and hospitals that serve the well-to-do. In 2009 and 2010
column3: a spate of high-profile deaths brought out the severity of the problem
column4: even for the relatively well off Yangonites. The wealthy do not rely on domestic hospitals and travel abroad
column5: usually Bangkok or Singapore
